**Article 6.10 — Insurance Maintenance and Cooperation (Pre-Closing Covenant)**

Section 6.10 Insurance Policies — Maintenance and Cooperation.

From the date hereof until the Closing Date, Seller shall cause the Company to:

(a) **Maintain Existing Policies Without Modification.** Maintain in full force and effect all insurance policies listed in Schedule 4.19(a), with coverage limits, deductibles, retentions, and terms no less favorable than those in effect as of the date hereof. The Company shall pay all premiums when due (including any installment payments, retrospective premium adjustments, or audit premiums) and shall not take any action (or fail to take any action required by the policies) that would void or materially limit coverage under any such policy. For the avoidance of doubt, the Company shall comply with all policy warranties, including the security controls warranty in the crime/cyber policy, and shall complete implementation of multi-signature wallet authorization no later than **[DATE 90 DAYS FROM SIGNING]**.

(b) **No Policy Modifications Without Buyer Consent.** Not modify, amend, cancel, non-renew, or allow to lapse any insurance policy listed in Schedule 4.19(a) without Buyer's prior written consent (not to be unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed), **except for**:

(i) **Ordinary Course Renewals:** Renewals of expiring policies on substantially similar terms (with coverage limits, deductibles/retentions, and covered perils equivalent or more favorable), provided that premium increases do not exceed **300%** of the expiring policy premium. For the crime/cyber and D&O policies, the parties acknowledge that premium increases of 200-300% are anticipated due to the March 2024 Hot Wallet Incident and pending regulatory investigations, and such increases shall be deemed "ordinary course" and not require Buyer consent.

(ii) **Supplemental Coverage Purchases:** Purchase of additional or supplemental insurance coverage (e.g., excess D&O layer, supplemental crime/cyber limit, separate regulatory penalty insurance) that enhances the Company's insurance program, provided Seller provides Buyer with 10 Business Days' prior written notice and copies of policy terms.

(c) **Notice of Coverage Issues.** Notify Buyer in writing within **48 hours** (two Business Days) of any of the following events:

(i) Receipt of any coverage denial letter, reservation of rights letter, or declaratory judgment action filed by an insurer challenging coverage for any pending claim;

(ii) Receipt of any notice of cancellation, non-renewal, or material modification to coverage terms from any insurer;

(iii) Filing of any coverage litigation by the Company against an insurer, or service of any complaint by an insurer against the Company seeking declaratory relief regarding coverage;

(iv) Settlement or resolution of any insurance claim, including amount paid by insurer and any release or waiver executed by the Company;

(v) Receipt of any communication from an insurer indicating that a policy limit may be exhausted or is projected to be exhausted within the next 12 months based on pending claims; or

(vi) Discovery of any facts that would constitute a breach of a policy warranty or that would trigger a policy exclusion for pending or future claims.

The notice shall describe in reasonable detail the nature of the event, provide copies of all relevant correspondence or court filings, and include the Company's preliminary assessment of the impact on insurance coverage for pending claims (Hot Wallet Incident crime/cyber claim, D&O coverage for SEC/CFTC/class action).

(d) **Crime Policy Mediation Cooperation.** With respect to the crime/cyber policy coverage dispute relating to the Hot Wallet Incident described in Section 4.19(b):

(i) **Participate in Mediation.** Seller shall cause the Company to participate in good faith in any mediation required by the insurance policy or requested by either the Company or the insurer. If the policy does not require mediation, Seller shall cause the Company to propose mediation to the insurer within **30 days** after the date hereof if no mediation has yet been scheduled.

(ii) **Buyer Participation Rights.** Seller shall cause the Company to: (A) provide Buyer with at least **15 Business Days' advance written notice** of any scheduled mediation session; (B) invite Buyer (and Buyer's coverage counsel) to attend the mediation as observers (provided that Buyer and its counsel agree to maintain confidentiality of all mediation communications in accordance with Federal Rule of Evidence 408 and applicable state mediation privilege statutes); and (C) consult with Buyer before executing any settlement agreement or release with the insurer if such settlement would result in insurance recovery of less than **$22 million**.

(iii) **Buyer Consultation Obligation (Not Control).** Prior to accepting or rejecting any settlement offer from the insurer, Seller shall provide Buyer with: (A) a written summary of the settlement terms offered; (B) coverage counsel's opinion on the strengths and weaknesses of the insurer's coverage defenses and the likelihood of success in coverage litigation if the settlement offer is rejected; and (C) Seller's recommendation regarding acceptance or rejection. Buyer shall have **five Business Days** to provide Seller with written comments, questions, or concerns regarding the proposed settlement. **However, the final decision whether to accept or reject the settlement offer shall remain solely with Seller** (and the Company) prior to Closing. Post-Closing, all litigation and settlement decisions shall be made by Buyer (as the Company's new owner) in consultation with the Company's coverage counsel.

(iv) **Litigation Strategy Coordination.** If mediation fails and coverage litigation is filed (whether by the Company against the insurer or by the insurer seeking declaratory relief against the Company), Seller shall: (A) provide Buyer with copies of all pleadings, motions, discovery requests/responses, expert reports, and court orders within **five Business Days** of filing or receipt; (B) invite Buyer's coverage counsel to participate in litigation strategy sessions (conference calls with coverage counsel and litigation counsel) as observers; and (C) consult with Buyer before making any material litigation decisions including: (1) selection of expert witnesses (cybersecurity expert, damages expert); (2) dispositive motion strategy (motion to dismiss, motion for summary judgment); (3) settlement negotiations during litigation; (4) trial/mediation/arbitration election.

For the avoidance of doubt, this consultation obligation does NOT give Buyer control over litigation decisions or create a joint attorney-client relationship between the Company and Buyer. The purpose is to facilitate information sharing and ensure that Buyer (as the future owner post-Closing) is informed about coverage litigation status and strategy, given Buyer's economic interest through the Insurance Gap Escrow.

(e) **D&O Policy Carrier Communications.** With respect to the D&O policy and the SEC, CFTC, and class action matters described in Sections 4.12(a), 4.13(b), and 4.14(c):

(i) **Provide Buyer with Copies of Carrier Correspondence.** Within **five Business Days** of receipt, provide Buyer with copies of: (A) all reservation of rights letters, coverage position letters, or declaratory judgment complaints received from the D&O carrier; (B) all billing statements or invoices submitted to the D&O carrier for defense costs (with redaction of attorney work product or attorney-client privileged information, but showing total defense costs invoiced and paid by carrier to date); (C) any correspondence with the carrier regarding interpretation of the Investigation Costs Only endorsement, aggregate policy limit depletion, or application of policy exclusions; and (D) any notice from the carrier that the $75 million aggregate policy limit is projected to be exhausted based on pending claims.

(ii) **Consult Before Modifying Investigation Costs Only Endorsement.** Not agree to any modification, amendment, or clarification of the Investigation Costs Only endorsement described in Section 4.19(c)(i) **without Buyer's prior written consent**, which consent may be withheld in Buyer's sole discretion. For the avoidance of doubt, if the D&O carrier offers to "buy back" coverage for regulatory penalties in exchange for additional premium or reduced limits, Seller must consult with Buyer and obtain Buyer's written consent before accepting such offer. (Rationale: Any modification to the Investigation Costs Only endorsement directly impacts the $262.5M uninsured regulatory penalty gap, which is the subject of Seller's indemnification obligations under Sections 8.2(a)(vii) and (viii). Buyer has a direct economic interest in determining whether to pay additional premium to obtain regulatory penalty coverage vs. relying on Seller indemnification.)

(iii) **Cooperate on Supplemental D&O Tower Evaluation.** Reasonably cooperate with Buyer (at Buyer's expense) in evaluating options to purchase supplemental D&O coverage (excess of the existing $75 million tower) for the period following Closing, including: (A) providing the Company's financial statements, regulatory investigation summaries, and litigation status updates to excess D&O carrier underwriters; (B) making the Company's Chief Financial Officer and General Counsel available for underwriting calls with excess carriers (at mutually convenient times, not to exceed four hours total time commitment); and (C) executing insurance applications for excess coverage if Buyer elects to bind such coverage. **Cost Allocation:** The cost of any supplemental D&O coverage obtained by Buyer for the post-Closing period shall be borne **100% by Buyer**, and Seller shall have no obligation to fund or subsidize such coverage. However, if supplemental coverage is obtained and subsequently pays claims that would otherwise be subject to Seller's indemnification obligations under Sections 8.2(a)(xii)(B) (D&O Exhaustion Indemnification), the insurance recovery shall reduce Seller's indemnification obligation dollar-for-dollar.

(f) **No Material Changes to Claims Handling.** Not settle, compromise, waive, release, or otherwise resolve any pending insurance claim (Hot Wallet Incident crime/cyber claim, D&O defense cost submissions for SEC/CFTC/class action) without: (i) providing Buyer with **15 Business Days' prior written notice** of the proposed settlement or resolution, (ii) providing Buyer with a copy of the proposed settlement agreement, release, or other documentation, and (iii) consulting with Buyer regarding Buyer's concerns (if any) about the impact of the settlement on future coverage or Seller's indemnification obligations. For the avoidance of doubt, Seller retains final decision-making authority regarding claim settlements prior to Closing, but must engage in good faith consultation with Buyer before finalizing any settlement.

(g) **Preservation of Subrogation Rights.** Not execute any release or waiver that would impair Seller's subrogation rights under Section 8.2(a)(xii)(D). If any settlement agreement with an insurer includes a release of claims, Seller shall cause the Company to negotiate a carve-out preserving Seller's subrogation rights to the extent Seller makes indemnification payments to Buyer under Section 8.2(a)(xii). The release language should provide: "This Release does not waive or release any subrogation rights of [Seller Name] arising from any indemnification payments made by [Seller Name] to [Buyer Name] under Section 8.2(a)(xii) of the Stock Purchase Agreement dated [DATE], and [Seller Name] shall be subrogated to all rights of [Company Name] against [Insurer Name] to the extent of such indemnification payments."

## IV.I. CLASS ACTION LITIGATION — JOHNSON V. CRYPTOTRADE EXCHANGE LLC

### A. Legal Framework

Class action litigation arising from cryptocurrency exchange security breaches implicates multiple areas of law: breach of contract (violation of terms of service), negligence (duty to implement reasonable security measures), breach of fiduciary duty (for custodial exchanges), and potential punitive damages for gross negligence. The enforceability of arbitration clauses in consumer agreements provides the most significant procedural defense, with the Federal Arbitration Act preempting state-law challenges to class action waivers.

#### 1. Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23 — Class Certification Standards

To obtain class certification, plaintiffs must satisfy both Rule 23(a) prerequisites and Rule 23(b) requirements.¹

**Rule 23(a) Prerequisites:**

*Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. v. Dukes*, 564 U.S. 338 (2011), clarified the commonality requirement under Rule 23(a)(2): "What matters to class certification . . . is not the raising of common 'questions'—even in droves—but, rather the capacity of a classwide proceeding to generate common answers apt to drive the resolution of the litigation."² The Supreme Court held that claims must depend upon a common contention that is capable of classwide resolution—meaning the determination of its truth or falsity will resolve an issue central to the validity of each claim in one stroke.³

**(1) Numerosity:** The class must be so numerous that joinder of all members is impracticable. Courts routinely certify classes with more than 40 members.⁴

**(2) Commonality:** There must be questions of law or fact common to the class. Under *Wal-Mart*, a single common question capable of classwide resolution suffices.⁵

**(3) Typicality:** The claims of the representative parties must be typical of the claims of the class. Lead plaintiff's claims must arise from the same event, practice, or course of conduct that gives rise to the claims of other class members.⁶

**(4) Adequacy:** The representative parties must fairly and adequately protect the interests of the class, requiring competent counsel and no conflicts of interest between lead plaintiff and class members.⁷

**Rule 23(b)(3) Requirements:**

**(1) Predominance:** Questions of law or fact common to class members must predominate over any questions affecting only individual members. Courts analyze whether common questions can be resolved through common proof or whether individual issues require separate mini-trials for each class member.⁸

**(2) Superiority:** A class action must be superior to other available methods for fairly and efficiently adjudicating the controversy. Where individual claims are small (economically infeasible to litigate separately), class actions are typically superior.⁹

#### 2. Federal Arbitration Act and Class Action Waivers

The Federal Arbitration Act creates a "liberal federal policy favoring arbitration agreements."¹⁰ In *AT&T Mobility LLC v. Concepcion*, 563 U.S. 333 (2011), the Supreme Court held that the FAA preempts state-law rules that prohibit enforcement of class action waivers in consumer arbitration agreements.¹¹ The Court reasoned that class arbitration "interferes with fundamental attributes of arbitration and thus creates a scheme inconsistent with the FAA."¹²

**State-Law Unconscionability Challenges:**

While state unconscionability doctrine remains applicable to arbitration agreements, *Concepcion* dramatically limited its scope. Courts applying unconscionability must show both:

**(1) Procedural unconscionability:** Lack of meaningful choice (adhesion contract), lack of conspicuousness, oppressive circumstances at contract formation.¹³

**(2) Substantive unconscionability:** One-sided terms that unreasonably favor the stronger party, deprivation of substantive rights.¹⁴

Post-*Concepcion*, courts have consistently enforced arbitration clauses with class action waivers in cryptocurrency exchange user agreements, even where the agreements are adhesive.¹⁵

**Ninth Circuit Application:**

*Bielski v. Coinbase*, No. 22-16506 (9th Cir. 2024), exemplifies the modern trend. The Ninth Circuit reversed a district court's denial of Coinbase's motion to compel arbitration, finding that even "low levels of procedural and substantive unconscionability" were insufficient to invalidate an arbitration clause under California law.¹⁶ The court emphasized that arbitration provisions in consumer contracts are routinely adhesive, and adhesion alone does not render a contract unconscionable absent additional oppressive factors.¹⁷

#### 3. Negligence and Duty of Care for Cryptocurrency Custodians

Cryptocurrency exchanges operating custodial wallets owe customers a duty to implement reasonable security measures to protect digital assets.¹⁸ The standard of care analysis considers:

**(1) Foreseeability:** Are cyberattacks foreseeable in the cryptocurrency industry? With over $2.7 billion stolen through crypto hacks in 2024,¹⁹ courts increasingly hold that cyberattacks are foreseeable events requiring reasonable precautions.

**(2) Industry Standards:** Courts evaluate whether the defendant's security measures comported with industry best practices. Multi-signature wallets, multi-factor authentication, cold storage for majority of assets, and employee security training are recognized industry standards.²⁰

**(3) Causation:** Plaintiffs must establish that the defendant's negligence was the proximate cause of their injuries. The superseding cause doctrine may break the chain of causation if an unforeseeable criminal act intervenes, but courts generally hold that inadequate security measures that create opportunities for foreseeable crimes do not break causation.²¹

**Gross Negligence Standard:**

Punitive damages require a showing of gross negligence: conduct exhibiting "want of even scant care" or an "extreme departure from ordinary care."²² Single-credential access to hot wallets containing hundreds of millions of dollars may satisfy this heightened standard, particularly where multi-signature authorization is industry standard practice.²³

#### 4. Collateral Estoppel from Regulatory Settlements

Under *Parklane Hosiery Co. v. Shore*, 439 U.S. 322 (1979), offensive use of collateral estoppel permits plaintiffs to preclude a defendant from relitigating an issue the defendant previously litigated and lost against another party.²⁴ For collateral estoppel to apply: (1) the issue must be identical to one in the prior action; (2) the issue must have been actually litigated; (3) determination of the issue must have been necessary to the prior judgment; and (4) the party against whom estoppel is asserted must have had a full and fair opportunity to litigate.²⁵

**SEC Settlement Admissions:**

If CTE's SEC settlement (projected Q3 2025) includes admissions regarding inadequate security controls or failure to safeguard customer assets, plaintiffs in the class action may invoke collateral estoppel to establish CTE's negligence or breach of duty. However, most SEC settlements contain "neither admit nor deny" language specifically to avoid creating collateral estoppel exposure.²⁶

### B. Application to Transaction

#### B.1 Johnson v. CryptoTrade Exchange LLC — Case Profile and Claims

**Case Identification:**

*Johnson v. CryptoTrade Exchange LLC*, Case No. [filed W.D. Texas, June 2024] (consolidated from four separate complaints).²⁷ Lead plaintiff Marcus Johnson allegedly lost $127,000 in the September 18, 2024 hot wallet hack.²⁸

**Procedural Posture:**

The case is at the pleading stage. CTE likely filed a motion to dismiss under Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6) (failure to state a claim) and/or a motion to compel arbitration under the Federal Arbitration Act. A class certification motion would be premature until discovery is completed.²⁹

**Class Definition:**

All U.S. customers who held cryptocurrency on CTE's platform on September 18, 2024, and whose assets were stolen in the hot wallet hack. Class size: 1,842 customers. Average claim value: $25,515 ($47M ÷ 1,842 customers).³⁰

**Claims Asserted:**

**(1) Breach of Contract:**

CTE's Terms of Service likely contain representations regarding security measures such as "industry-leading security," "bank-grade encryption," or "best practices for asset protection." Plaintiffs allege CTE breached these express warranties by implementing single-credential access to hot wallet management systems, failing to require multi-signature authorization, and inadequate employee phishing training.³¹

**(2) Negligence:**

CTE owed customers a duty of care to implement reasonable security measures. The breach consisted of: (a) single-credential access to $1.2 billion hot wallet (8% of $15B total assets under custody), violating industry standard of 2-5% hot wallet allocation;³² (b) failure to implement multi-signature wallets; (c) inadequate employee training (employee clicked phishing link); (d) failure to implement least-privilege access controls. Causation is established through the security vulnerability enabling the theft. Damages are the $47 million stolen.³³

**(3) Breach of Fiduciary Duty:**

Custodial cryptocurrency exchanges arguably hold customer assets "in trust," creating a fiduciary relationship requiring CTE to act with utmost care and loyalty in safeguarding customer funds.³⁴ CTE allegedly breached its fiduciary duty by prioritizing operational convenience (single-credential access) over asset security, demonstrating inadequate care for customer interests.³⁵

**(4) Punitive Damages:**

Plaintiffs seek $50M-$150M in punitive damages, alleging CTE's single-credential access to $1.2 billion constituted gross negligence—an extreme departure from industry standards demonstrating reckless indifference to customer asset safety.³⁶

**Damages Theory:**

Although CTE reimbursed all affected customers for their losses ($47M total), plaintiffs argue they are entitled to consequential damages (loss of use of funds, opportunity costs), emotional distress, and punitive damages as punishment for CTE's gross negligence regardless of whether compensatory damages were remediated.³⁷

#### B.2 Motion to Compel Arbitration — 70-80% Enforcement Probability

**Arbitration Clause Analysis:**

CTE's Terms of Service Section 15.2 (hypothetical provision) likely contains: (1) requirement for binding arbitration; (2) class action waiver (no class arbitrations or class actions permitted); (3) American Arbitration Association ("AAA") Consumer Arbitration Rules; (4) delegation clause (arbitrator decides arbitrability disputes); (5) waiver of jury trial.³⁸

**2024 Cryptocurrency Exchange Arbitration Precedents:**

Federal courts in 2024 overwhelmingly enforced arbitration clauses in cryptocurrency exchange user agreements:

*Bielski v. Coinbase* (9th Cir. 2024): Reversed district court and enforced Coinbase's arbitration clause, rejecting unconscionability challenges based on adhesion, delegation clause unfairness, and lack of mutuality.³⁹

Georgia federal court (Coinbase) (2024): Found only "minimal degree of procedural unconscionability" from adhesive nature; "Nothing in the record suggests Coinbase was the plaintiff's only option for cryptocurrency services."⁴⁰

*Binance* arbitration enforcement (November 2024): District court rejected all unconscionability challenges (adhesiveness, non-mutuality, lack of user sophistication, cost-splitting) and compelled arbitration.⁴¹

Bloomberg Law reported "a sharp decline in active civil suits against cryptocurrency exchanges" in 2024 due to "concerted electronic contracting legal strategies that have updated terms of service provisions and moved such cases to arbitration."⁴²

**CTE's Motion Strategy:**

CTE should file its motion to compel arbitration within 60 days of filing the answer (industry standard practice to avoid waiver).⁴³ The motion should argue: (1) valid arbitration agreement (clickwrap acceptance binds customers); (2) claims fall within arbitration scope (all disputes arising from account use); (3) FAA preempts state-law unconscionability challenges (*Concepcion*); (4) adhesion alone insufficient for unconscionability (*Bielski*); (5) delegation clause requires arbitrator to decide arbitrability.⁴⁴

**Plaintiff Opposition:**

Plaintiffs will argue: (1) procedural unconscionability (buried in lengthy Terms of Service, no meaningful choice, take-it-or-leave-it); (2) substantive unconscionability (one-sided terms, class waiver prevents vindication of federal statutory rights); (3) inadequate notice of arbitration clause; (4) gross negligence claims not arbitrable (public policy exception).⁴⁵

**Court's Probable Ruling:**

Based on 2024 precedent, **70-80% probability** court grants motion to compel arbitration and dismisses class action (or stays pending arbitration).⁴⁶ If granted, 1,842 customers must pursue individual arbitration claims. Given average claim value of $25,515 and arbitration costs ($200-$2,000 AAA filing fee + $10,000-$50,000 attorney fees), most customers will not pursue arbitration, effectively terminating the litigation.⁴⁷

**Strategic Impact on Settlement:**

- **If arbitration compelled (70-80% probability):** Settlement leverage shifts dramatically to CTE. Settlement value: $5M-$15M nuisance value (cost of administering potential individual arbitrations + avoiding reputational harm from protracted arbitration demands).⁴⁸

- **If arbitration denied (20-30% probability):** Class action proceeds. Settlement value: $30M-$50M (15-25% of $107M-$217M claimed damages).⁴⁹ CTE faces risk of $50M-$150M punitive damages verdict if case proceeds to trial.⁵⁰

#### B.3 Class Certification Analysis — 60-70% Certification Probability (If Arbitration Fails)

**NOTE:** This analysis assumes the arbitration clause is unenforceable or does not contain a class action waiver (20-30% probability scenario).

**Rule 23(a) Prerequisites (Easily Satisfied):**

**(1) Numerosity:** 1,842 customers clearly satisfies numerosity (courts certify classes with 40+ members).⁵¹

**(2) Commonality:** Common questions include: Did CTE owe a duty of care to safeguard customer assets? Did CTE's single-credential access breach industry standards? Was the Lazarus Group attack foreseeable? These questions generate common answers driving the litigation (*Wal-Mart* standard).⁵²

**(3) Typicality:** Lead plaintiff's claims (breach of contract, negligence, fiduciary duty based on hot wallet hack) are typical of all 1,842 class members' claims arising from the same September 18, 2024 incident.⁵³

**(4) Adequacy:** Experienced class action counsel and no apparent conflicts between lead plaintiff and class members satisfy adequacy.⁵⁴

**Rule 23(b)(3) Predominance (Key Battleground):**

**CTE's Strongest Defense — Individual Reliance Issues:**

CTE will argue that individual questions predominate: (1) Did each customer read the Terms of Service security representations? (2) Did each customer rely on CTE's specific security promises? (3) Would CTE's alleged security failures have prevented the hack as to each individual customer's specific assets?⁵⁵

**Plaintiffs' Response:**

(1) **Common course of conduct:** CTE uniformly failed to implement multi-signature authorization for all customers. No individual inquiry needed—the security vulnerability affected all customers identically.⁵⁶

(2) **Damages formula:** Each customer's stolen funds are precisely known (CTE has records). No individual damages calculation required—simple formula: stolen amount per customer.⁵⁷

(3) **No reliance required for negligence:** Breach of duty of care does not require individual reliance on representations. If CTE breached its duty to implement reasonable security, all customers were harmed regardless of whether they read Terms of Service.⁵⁸

(4) **Fraud-on-the-market analogy:** While typically applied to securities fraud, courts have extended presumptions of reliance to data breach cases where defendants made uniform misrepresentations to all consumers.⁵⁹

**2024 Data Breach Class Action Trend:**

WilmerHale's 2024 Year in Review reported that courts increasingly certify data breach class actions where the defendant's security failure was uniform across all plaintiffs, rejecting arguments that individual reliance issues defeat predominance.⁶⁰ Multiple 2024 decisions (*In re Accellion, Inc. Data Breach Litig.*, *Baton v. Ledger SAS*) denied motions to dismiss negligence claims and found predominance satisfied where security vulnerabilities uniformly affected all class members.⁶¹

**Predominance Likelihood: 60-70%**

CTE's uniform security failure (single-credential access to hot wallets) likely predominates over individual reliance issues. Damages are mechanically calculable from CTE's records. The critical liability question—whether CTE breached its duty of care—applies uniformly to all class members.⁶²

**Rule 23(b)(3) Superiority (80-90% Likelihood):**

With average claim value of $25,515, individual litigation is economically infeasible. Class action is far superior to 1,842 separate lawsuits. CTE cannot realistically defend 1,842 individual cases.⁶³

**Overall Class Certification Probability: 60-70%** (conditional on reaching certification stage after surviving motion to dismiss and arbitration challenge).

**Key Risk Drivers:**

1. **Arbitration enforcement probability (70-80%):** Single most important variable. If arbitration compelled, exposure drops from $40M-$50M to $10M-$12M.⁸⁶

2. **Punitive damages multiplier:** If case proceeds to trial and jury finds gross negligence (single-credential access to $1.2B), punitive damages could be 2× to 6× compensatory damages ($50M-$150M range).⁸⁷ Trial avoidance is critical.

3. **SEC collateral estoppel risk:** If SEC settlement (expected Q3 2025) includes admissions regarding inadequate security controls, plaintiffs can use offensive collateral estoppel to establish negligence, increasing settlement leverage by $10M-$20M.⁸⁸

4. **D&O insurance coverage:** If D&O policy excludes punitive damages or gross negligence settlements, CTE (and by extension, Seller under indemnification provisions) bears uninsured settlement costs.⁸⁹

#### Detailed Cross-References

**Finding 1: Arbitration Enforcement (70-80% Probability)**

This finding directly affects:

- **Section IV.H (Insurance Coverage)** at ¶18-22: D&O insurance defense costs depend on litigation complexity and duration. If arbitration compelled, defense costs are $2M-$3M (motion practice through arbitration ruling). If class action proceeds, defense costs are $8M-$19M (through class certification, discovery, summary judgment).⁹⁰ The $6M-$16M variance affects D&O policy exhaustion risk and triggers Article 8.2(a)(xii)(B) (Insurance Gap Indemnification) if D&O limits are insufficient.⁹¹

- **Contract Provision Article 8.2(a)(xiii)(D)**: The arbitration success reduction clause provides that if CTE's motion to compel arbitration is granted, Seller's indemnification obligations are capped at $5M total (100% of settlement up to $7.5M + 50% of defense costs), recognizing the dramatically reduced exposure when class action is dismissed.⁹²

Legal doctrine: The Federal Arbitration Act, 9 U.S.C. § 2, creates a federal policy favoring arbitration that preempts state-law barriers.⁹³ *Concepcion*'s holding that class action waivers are enforceable fundamentally alters class action exposure for companies with enforceable arbitration clauses in consumer agreements.⁹⁴

**Finding 2: SEC Collateral Estoppel Application (60-70% Probability if SEC Settles with Admissions)**

This finding directly affects:

- **Section IV.A (SEC Enforcement)** at ¶45-52: The SEC settlement (expected Q3 2025) will determine whether CTE must admit to inadequate security controls or other negligence that plaintiffs can use in the class action.⁹⁵ If SEC settlement includes admission that CTE's security controls were inadequate to protect customer assets, this satisfies the "breach of duty" element of plaintiffs' negligence claim under offensive collateral estoppel doctrine.⁹⁶

- **Contract Provision Article 8.2(a)(xiii)(E)**: The SEC collateral estoppel adjustment clause reduces the Buyer Threshold in the indemnification provision from $10M to $5M if SEC settlement admissions are used for collateral estoppel in the class action, recognizing the increased settlement value created by the regulatory admission.⁹⁷

Legal doctrine: Under *Parklane Hosiery Co. v. Shore*, 439 U.S. 322 (1979), offensive collateral estoppel permits a plaintiff to prevent a defendant from relitigating an issue the defendant previously litigated and lost (or admitted) in an action with another party.⁹⁸ The doctrine applies when: (1) the issue is identical; (2) actually litigated (or admitted in settlement); (3) necessary to the prior judgment; and (4) defendant had full and fair opportunity to litigate.⁹⁹

**Finding 3: Gross Negligence Standard**

This finding directly affects:

- **Section IV.G (Cybersecurity)** at ¶28-35: The cybersecurity analysis documents CTE's use of single-credential access to hot wallet management systems controlling $1.2B in customer assets (8% of $15B total AUC).¹⁰⁰ Multi-signature wallets are industry standard for cryptocurrency custodians to eliminate single points of failure.¹⁰¹ CTE's failure to implement multi-sig constitutes an "extreme departure from ordinary care" potentially satisfying the gross negligence standard.¹⁰²

- **Contract Provision Article 3.23(b)**: The representation on security controls requires Seller to disclose that CTE operated single-credential access until post-breach remediation in October 2024, and that this security architecture fell below industry standard practice for exchanges of CTE's size.¹⁰³

Legal doctrine: Gross negligence requires conduct exhibiting "want of even scant care" or "extreme departure from ordinary care."¹⁰⁴ Unlike ordinary negligence (which permits only compensatory damages), gross negligence allows punitive damages designed to punish and deter.¹⁰⁵ Tennessee and Connecticut statutory safe harbors (2024 laws) limit cybersecurity liability to gross negligence or willful misconduct, reflecting legislative recognition that ordinary negligence standard is too harsh for cybersecurity breaches.¹⁰⁶

**Finding 4: D&O Insurance Coverage Limitations**

This finding directly affects:

- **Section IV.H (Insurance Coverage)** at ¶55-68: D&O policies typically provide Side C (entity securities coverage) for securities class actions, covering defense costs and settlements.¹⁰⁷ However, punitive damages are often excluded or covered only "where insurable under law."¹⁰⁸ Texas law permits insurance coverage for punitive damages resulting from gross negligence (but not intentional conduct).¹⁰⁹ If plaintiff proves gross negligence, $50M-$150M punitive damages may be uninsured, creating a coverage gap requiring Seller indemnification or Buyer self-funding.¹¹⁰

- **Contract Provision Article 8.2(a)(xiii)(C)**: The D&O tower exhaustion sharing clause provides that if class action settlement or judgment exceeds available D&O coverage (after SEC and CFTC defense costs deplete the tower), the excess is shared 50/50 between Seller and Buyer up to a $25M Seller cap.¹¹¹

Legal doctrine: Texas Insurance Code permits insurance coverage for punitive damages arising from gross negligence but not intentional wrongdoing.¹¹² Federal securities class actions routinely incur covered defense costs under D&O policies,¹¹³ but settlement coverage depends on exclusions for fraud, willful misconduct, or punitive damages.¹¹⁴

```
        (A) Release $5 million to Seller (recognizing reduced class action settlement risk
            when SEC admission unavailable for collateral estoppel);
        (B) Retain $20 million in CAL Escrow for class action settlement and defense costs.

    (iv) Class Certification Denial Release. If the class action is not certified under Fed.
         R. Civ. P. 23 (whether due to motion to dismiss being granted, class certification
         motion denied, or plaintiffs' voluntary dismissal), within 5 Business Days after the
         certification ruling becomes final and non-appealable:
        (A) Release $10 million to Seller (recognizing that individual cases or small group
            settlements produce lower exposure than certified class);
        (B) Retain $15 million in CAL Escrow for potential individual plaintiff settlements
            or remaining litigation costs.

    (v) Settlement or Judgment Funding. Upon execution of a binding settlement agreement or
        entry of final judgment in the class action (including any punitive damages award),
        the CAL Escrow shall be applied to satisfy Seller's indemnification obligations under
        Article 8.2(a)(xiii) in the following order of priority:
        (A) First, Buyer's Threshold: The first $10 million (or $5 million if SEC collateral
            estoppel applies per Article 8.2(a)(xiii)(E)) of settlement or judgment shall be
            paid by Buyer (not from CAL Escrow);
        (B) Second, Seller's Share from CAL Escrow: Apply CAL Escrow funds to pay Seller's
            indemnification obligation above the Buyer Threshold, up to $25 million (or the
            then-remaining CAL Escrow balance after any prior releases);
        (C) Third, Seller's Additional Payment: If settlement or judgment exceeds $35 million
            ($10M Buyer Threshold + $25M CAL Escrow), Seller shall pay the excess to Buyer
            within 10 Business Days of settlement execution or judgment entry, up to Seller's
            $40 million cap under Article 8.2(a)(xiii)(A);
        (D) Fourth, Buyer's Excess: If settlement or judgment exceeds $50 million ($10M Buyer
            Threshold + $40M Seller Cap), Buyer bears the excess above $50 million.

    Settlement Funding Examples:

    Example 1 (Arbitration Enforced, Nuisance Settlement $10M):
        Buyer pays: $10M (threshold) = $10M
        Seller obligation: $0 (below threshold)
        CAL Escrow applied: $0
        Remaining CAL Escrow released to Seller: $25M (full escrow)

    Example 2 (Class Certified, Mid-Range Settlement $37.5M):
        Buyer pays: $10M (threshold) = $10M
        Seller obligation: $27.5M (above threshold, within cap)
        CAL Escrow applied: $25M (partial satisfaction of Seller obligation)
        Seller additional payment: $2.5M (to Buyer within 10 days)
        Remaining CAL Escrow: $0 (fully applied)

    Example 3 (Severe, Settlement $60M Exceeding Cap):
        Buyer pays: $10M (threshold) + $10M (excess over $50M cap) = $20M
        Seller obligation: $40M (capped)
        CAL Escrow applied: $25M (partial satisfaction)
        Seller additional payment: $15M (to reach $40M cap)
        Remaining CAL Escrow: $0 (fully applied)

    (vi) Defense Cost Funding During Litigation. The CAL Escrow may be used to fund Seller's
         50% share of defense costs as they are incurred (rather than waiting for final
         resolution), provided that:
        (A) Buyer provides Escrow Agent with:
            (1) Invoices from defense counsel and expert witnesses showing costs incurred;
            (2) Evidence of Buyer's payment of its 50% share of such costs; and
            (3) Written certification that the costs are reasonable and necessary defense
                costs under Article 8.2(a)(xiii)(B);
        (B) Maximum cumulative draw for defense costs: $10 million (reflecting Seller's
            maximum defense cost obligation under Article 8.2(a)(xiii)(B));
        (C) Defense cost draws reduce the CAL Escrow available for settlement funding under
            subsection (b)(v);
        (D) If Seller's ultimate defense cost obligation under Article 8.2(a)(xiii)(B) is
            less than amounts drawn for defense costs, excess amounts shall be credited
            toward Seller's settlement obligations or released to Seller if no settlement
            obligation remains.

    (vii) Final Release Date. On December 31, 2029 (five years post-Closing), if Johnson v.
          CryptoTrade Exchange LLC has not been fully and finally resolved (including all
          appeals), the CAL Escrow shall be released as follows:
        (A) If settlement negotiations are ongoing or settlement is pending court approval,
            retain in escrow an amount equal to 150% of the estimated settlement amount per
            then-current defense counsel assessment, and release remainder to Seller;
        (B) If litigation is ongoing with no settlement negotiations, retain in escrow an
            amount equal to Seller's estimated maximum exposure per then-current defense
            counsel assessment (capped at remaining escrow balance), and release remainder
            to Seller;
        (C) If no claims have been asserted by Buyer under Article 8.2(a)(xiii) and the
            litigation has been dormant (no activity for 12+ consecutive months), release
            entire remaining CAL Escrow balance to Seller.

(c) Interest on CAL Escrow. All interest or other investment income earned on the CAL Escrow
shall be:
    (i) Allocated 50/50 between Buyer and Seller;
    (ii) Distributed annually on each anniversary of the Closing Date while escrow remains
         open;
    (iii) Taxable to the party receiving distribution; Escrow Agent shall issue IRS Forms
          1099 to Buyer and Seller for their respective shares.

(d) Coordination with Other Escrows and Indemnification Provisions.

    (i) Coordination with D&O Exhaustion Sub-Account (Article 2.3(v)(a)(ii)). The CAL Escrow
        ($25 million) is separate from and in addition to the D&O Exhaustion Sub-Account
        ($20 million established under Article 2.3(v)(a)(ii)). Application priority:
        (A) First: Directors and officers liability insurance policy pays covered defense
            costs and settlement amounts up to available policy limits;
        (B) Second: If D&O policy limits are exhausted, the D&O Exhaustion Sub-Account
            ($20M) funds Seller's 50% share of excess amounts per Article 8.2(a)(xii)(B);
        (C) Third: After D&O Exhaustion Sub-Account is depleted, the CAL Escrow funds
            Seller's remaining indemnification obligations under Article 8.2(a)(xiii).

    (ii) Coordination with Hot Wallet Incident Indemnification (Article 8.2(a)(xi)). If
         customers' class action claims overlap with hot wallet incident losses covered by
         Article 8.2(a)(xi), and Seller has made payment to Buyer under Article 8.2(a)(xi)(C)
         (insurance claim denial indemnification), such payments shall be credited against
         amounts owed under Article 8.2(a)(xiii) to prevent double payment. The CAL Escrow
         shall not be applied to the same losses twice.

    (iii) Coordination with General Indemnification Escrow (Article 2.3(v)). The CAL Escrow
          is a special-purpose escrow dedicated solely to class action indemnification under
          Article 8.2(a)(xiii). Buyer may not seek payment from the CAL Escrow for other
          indemnification claims under Article 8.2. Seller may not seek reduction of the CAL
          Escrow based on indemnification claims asserted under other Article 8.2 provisions.

    (iv) Set-Off Rights. Buyer's set-off rights under Article 8.2(a)(xiii)(K) apply to the
         CAL Escrow. If Seller fails to make any required additional payment under subsection
         (b)(v)(C) within 10 Business Days of demand, Buyer may: (A) draw additional funds
         from any other escrow or holdback under this Agreement; (B) offset against any
         amounts owed to Seller; or (C) pursue legal action for breach.

(e) Escrow Agent Provisions.

    (i) Escrow Agent shall be [Escrow Agent Name], a [state] trust company, or such other
        third-party escrow agent as Buyer and Seller mutually agree in writing. Escrow Agent's
        rights, duties, compensation, and liability shall be governed by the CAL Escrow
        Agreement (Exhibit F), which shall be consistent with this Article 2.3(vi).

    (ii) Escrow Agent fees and costs shall be shared 50/50 between Buyer and Seller and paid
         from CAL Escrow interest earnings to the extent available, with any shortfall paid
         50/50 by Buyer and Seller within 10 Business Days of Escrow Agent's invoice.

    (iii) Escrow Agent may rely upon any written certification or instruction signed by Buyer
          and Seller jointly. In the event of any dispute between Buyer and Seller regarding
          release of CAL Escrow funds, Escrow Agent may: (A) interplead the funds into court
          and seek discharge; (B) hold the funds until receiving a final, non-appealable
          court order directing disbursement; or (C) follow any other procedure set forth in
          the CAL Escrow Agreement.

    (iv) Neither Buyer nor Seller shall be liable to Escrow Agent for Escrow Agent's fees,
         costs, or expenses beyond the 50/50 sharing provided in subsection (e)(ii), except
         that the party seeking wrongful release of escrow funds (as determined by a court of
         competent jurisdiction) shall reimburse Escrow Agent for all fees, costs, and
         expenses incurred in defending against such party's wrongful claim.
```

##### Provision 5: Litigation Management Covenant

**Article 6.11: Class Action Litigation Management Covenant**

```
From the date of this Agreement through the earlier of the Closing Date or termination of this
Agreement (the "Covenant Period"):

(a) Seller's Affirmative Obligations. Seller shall cause the Company to undertake the following
actions with respect to Johnson v. CryptoTrade Exchange LLC, Case No. [●] (W.D. Texas) (the
"Class Action"):

    (i) Vigorous Defense. Conduct a vigorous and diligent defense of the Class Action,
        including:
        (A) Retaining competent class action defense counsel with experience in cryptocurrency,
            cybersecurity, and consumer litigation (Seller has retained [Firm Name], which
            Buyer has approved);
        (B) Filing and prosecuting the Company's motion to compel arbitration and dismiss or
            stay the class action under the Federal Arbitration Act, 9 U.S.C. § 2, with full
            briefing, oral argument, and appeal if necessary;
        (C) Filing a motion to dismiss under Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6) if defense counsel
            advises such motion has reasonable likelihood of success on any claims;
        (D) Asserting all available affirmative defenses, including but not limited to: (1) no
            actual damages (customers reimbursed $47 million); (2) force majeure (nation-state
            cyberattack); (3) no gross negligence (rapid response, voluntary reimbursement);
            (4) comparative fault (plaintiffs' inadequate security practices contributed to
            losses); (5) statute of limitations; (6) lack of standing for customers not
            affected by hack;
        (E) Responding to all discovery requests in a timely, complete, and accurate manner;
        (F) Preparing and presenting expert testimony on industry standards, causation, and
            damages;
        (G) Opposing plaintiffs' motion for class certification with expert testimony and
            briefing demonstrating failure of Rule 23(a) and (b)(3) requirements;
        (H) Conducting discovery to develop factual record supporting the Company's defenses,
            including but not limited to: (1) third-party subpoenas to blockchain forensics
            firms (Chainalysis, Elliptic) for North Korea attribution; (2) depositions of
            plaintiffs to establish that customers were made whole; (3) expert reports on
            reasonableness of the Company's security measures relative to industry standards;
            (4) evidence of the sophistication of the Lazarus Group cyberattack.

    (ii) Buyer Consultation and Information Sharing. Provide Buyer and Buyer's counsel with:
        (A) Copies of all pleadings, motions, oppositions, replies, declarations, exhibits,
            and orders filed in or issued by the court, within 3 Business Days of filing or
            receipt;
        (B) Copies of all written discovery (interrogatories, requests for production, requests
            for admission) served by or on the Company, within 3 Business Days of service;
        (C) Notice of all depositions, hearings, status conferences, settlement conferences,
            and oral arguments at least 5 Business Days in advance (or immediately upon
            scheduling if less than 5 days' notice), with invitation for Buyer's counsel to
            attend;
        (D) Monthly litigation status reports prepared by defense counsel, summarizing: (1)
            activities during the prior month; (2) anticipated activities for the following
            month; (3) updated settlement range and probability assessment; (4) defense costs
            incurred to date and projected through settlement; (5) any material developments
            or concerns;
        (E) Immediate notice (within 24 hours) of any: (1) settlement offers or demands
            exceeding $10 million; (2) court rulings on motions to dismiss, motions to compel
            arbitration, or class certification; (3) significant discovery disputes or
            sanctions motions; (4) indications from the court regarding its views on the
            merits; (5) changes in defense counsel or class counsel; (6) amendments to the
            complaint; (7) third-party subpoenas from regulators (SEC, CFTC) or law enforcement
            (FBI, DOJ) related to the Class Action.

    (iii) Settlement Approval Requirement. Not enter into any settlement agreement, consent
          judgment, stipulated dismissal, or other resolution of the Class Action without
          Buyer's prior written consent. For clarity:
        (A) Buyer's consent shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed;
        (B) Buyer's consent shall be deemed reasonable if: (1) the settlement amount does not
            exceed the probability-weighted expected settlement range in Article 3.23(d) by
            more than 25%; (2) defense counsel provides written opinion that settlement is
            reasonable and advisable; (3) settlement contains standard release and "no
            admission" language; (4) settlement does not require business practice changes
            beyond security enhancements already implemented; (5) settlement does not include
            injunctive relief, monitor appointment, or other ongoing compliance obligations
            beyond monetary payment;
        (C) Buyer shall respond to any settlement consent request within 5 Business Days of
            receipt, or consent shall be deemed granted;
        (D) If Buyer unreasonably withholds consent to a settlement that defense counsel
            recommends, and the Class Action proceeds to judgment or later settles for a
            higher amount, Seller's indemnification obligations under Article 8.2(a)(xiii)
            shall be capped at the settlement amount Buyer rejected (i.e., Buyer bears
            incremental risk from rejection of reasonable settlement);
        (E) Notwithstanding Buyer's consent right, Seller remains liable for indemnification
            under Article 8.2(a)(xiii) for settlements to which Buyer consents, subject to the
            terms and caps in that Section.

    (iv) Preservation of Arbitration Defense. Not take any action, or permit the Company to
         take any action, that would waive or undermine the Company's arbitration defense,
         including but not limited to:
        (A) Amending the Company's Terms of Service to remove, weaken, or limit the arbitration
            clause or class action waiver;
        (B) Making any stipulations or admissions that individual arbitration is impracticable,
            unconscionable, or inadequate to vindicate customers' rights;
        (C) Failing to timely file the motion to compel arbitration (deadline: 60 days after
            answer filed);
        (D) Engaging in litigation conduct inconsistent with intent to arbitrate (e.g.,
            extensive merits discovery before arbitration motion decided, failing to oppose
            class certification, settling with some plaintiffs in court while arbitration
            motion pending);
        (E) Offering to waive arbitration or class action waiver in settlement negotiations
            without Buyer's prior written consent;
        (F) Making public statements that the Company does not believe arbitration is
            appropriate for customer disputes or that the Company regrets including arbitration
            clauses in its Terms of Service.

    (v) Coordination with SEC and Regulatory Defense. Coordinate with SEC defense counsel (for
        the SEC Wells Notice matter described in Section IV.A) and CFTC defense counsel (for
        the CFTC investigation described in Section IV.C) to:
        (A) Ensure consistency in legal positions, factual representations, and defenses across
            all litigation and regulatory matters;
        (B) Seek to avoid SEC or CFTC settlement language that would create offensive
            collateral estoppel exposure in the Class Action (specifically, avoid admissions
            that the Company's security controls were inadequate, that the Company was
            negligent, or that the Company breached duties to customers);
        (C) If SEC settlement must include findings or admissions regarding security controls,
            seek to limit admissions to SEC-specific statutory violations (e.g., failure to
            register as broker-dealer) rather than common-law negligence or breach of duty;
        (D) Provide Buyer with advance notice (at least 10 Business Days) of any proposed SEC
            or CFTC settlement language that could be used for collateral estoppel in the
            Class Action, and consult with Buyer regarding whether to accept such language or
            negotiate alternative formulations;
        (E) If Buyer objects to proposed SEC/CFTC settlement language on grounds that it would
            materially increase Class Action settlement risk via collateral estoppel, Seller
            shall instruct regulatory counsel to negotiate alternative language, provided that
            Seller's obligation to accept alternative language is subject to whether the SEC/
            CFTC will agree (Seller is not guaranteeing SEC/CFTC will accept alternative
            language, only that Seller will make good-faith efforts).

    (vi) D&O Insurance Carrier Notice and Cooperation. With respect to the Company's directors
         and officers liability insurance policy covering the Class Action:
        (A) Maintain timely and complete notice to the D&O carrier as required by the policy
            (typically within 30 days of claim or suit, with supplemental notices of material
            developments);
        (B) Provide all information and documentation requested by the D&O carrier within
            required timeframes to avoid late notice or non-cooperation defenses;
        (C) Not make any admissions, settlements, or agreements that would prejudice the D&O
            carrier's rights or violate policy conditions without the carrier's (and Buyer's)
            prior consent;
        (D) Cooperate with any coverage counsel retained by the D&O carrier to assess coverage
            for the Class Action;
        (E) Provide Buyer with copies of all correspondence with the D&O carrier regarding the
            Class Action, including claim notices, carrier responses, reservation of rights
            letters, coverage positions, and reimbursement of defense costs;
        (F) Not agree to any carrier-proposed limitations on coverage, exclusions, or
            reservations of rights that would reduce coverage below the amounts described in
            Article 3.23(e) without Buyer's prior written consent.

    (vii) Defense Cost Reporting and Budgeting. Provide Buyer with:
        (A) Monthly defense cost reports showing: (1) defense costs incurred in the prior
            month (by category: attorney fees, expert fees, deposition costs, document review,
            court costs); (2) cumulative defense costs to date; (3) comparison to budget; (4)
            projected defense costs for the following 3 months and through expected settlement
            date;
        (B) Quarterly budgets for defense costs, prepared by defense counsel, showing
            anticipated activities and costs by category, submitted to Buyer at least 15 days
            before the start of each calendar quarter;
        (C) If actual defense costs in any month exceed the budgeted amount for that month by
            more than 20%, written explanation from defense counsel within 10 days after
            month-end, explaining the variance and whether it reflects increased scope of work
            or higher-than-expected rates/fees;
        (D) Annually (and upon Buyer's request, but not more than quarterly), detailed itemized
            invoices from defense counsel and all experts and consultants engaged in the Class
            Action defense, showing dates, descriptions of services, hours (for hourly billing),
            and amounts. Buyer shall treat such invoices as Confidential Information under
            Article 9.1.

(b) Seller's Negative Covenants (Prohibited Actions). Seller shall cause the Company NOT to:

    (i) Settle for Excessive Amount. Settle the Class Action for any amount exceeding $50
        million (the "Settlement Cap") without Buyer's prior written consent, which Buyer may
        withhold in its sole discretion. If Seller causes the Company to settle for an amount
        exceeding the Settlement Cap without Buyer's consent, Seller's indemnification
        obligation under Article 8.2(a)(xiii)(A) shall be uncapped, and Seller shall indemnify
        Buyer for the entire settlement amount, not just the amount above the Buyer Threshold.

    (ii) Admit Gross Negligence or Fraud. Make any admission or stipulation in the Class
         Action (whether in pleadings, discovery responses, settlement agreements, or court
         filings) that the Company committed gross negligence, fraud, intentional misconduct,
         or willful violations of law. Such admissions could: (A) preclude D&O insurance
         coverage; (B) increase punitive damages exposure; (C) create regulatory or criminal
         exposure. Seller may permit the Company to admit ordinary negligence if defense
         counsel advises that such admission is necessary to achieve reasonable settlement,
         provided Buyer consents.

    (iii) Agree to Injunctive Relief. Agree to any injunctive relief, consent decree, or
          court order that would: (A) require the Company to change its business practices
          beyond security enhancements already implemented per Article 6.12 (Cybersecurity
          Remediation Covenant); (B) appoint a monitor, special master, or independent auditor
          to oversee the Company's operations; (C) require periodic reporting to the court or
          plaintiffs' counsel beyond standard settlement compliance reporting; (D) restrict
          the Company's ability to modify its Terms of Service, fee structure, or operational
          practices; or (E) require the Company to establish a claims administration process
          or customer compensation fund beyond payment of the settlement amount.

    (iv) Terminate or Change Defense Counsel. Terminate or replace the Company's defense
         counsel in the Class Action without Buyer's prior written consent, unless: (A) defense
         counsel withdraws due to ethical conflict, malpractice, or firm dissolution; (B)
         defense counsel is demonstrably incompetent or failing to adequately represent the
         Company's interests; or (C) defense counsel's fees are grossly excessive compared to
         market rates for comparable firms. If termination/replacement is necessary, Seller
         shall: (1) consult with Buyer on selection of replacement counsel; (2) ensure seamless
         transition with no loss of attorney-client privilege or work product protection; (3)
         obtain Buyer's approval of replacement counsel (not to be unreasonably withheld).

    (v) Make Public Statements. Make or permit the Company to make any public statements
        (press releases, social media posts, blog posts, investor presentations, conference
        remarks) regarding the Class Action, the September 2024 hot wallet incident, or the
        Company's security practices, without Buyer's prior review and consent, except:
        (A) Statements required by law, court order, or regulatory requirement (e.g., SEC
            filing disclosure, state money transmitter examination response), provided Buyer
            receives advance notice (at least 3 Business Days if practicable, or immediately
            if not) and opportunity to comment;
        (B) Routine customer communications regarding: (1) the Company's reimbursement of
            affected customers; (2) security enhancements implemented; (3) commitment to
            customer asset protection, provided such communications do not admit liability,
            negligence, or wrongdoing;
        (C) Statements to customers in individual customer service interactions (emails, phone
            calls, chat support), provided such statements follow script approved by defense
            counsel and do not admit liability or provide information that could be used
            against the Company in the Class Action.

(c) Buyer's Rights During Covenant Period. Buyer shall have the following rights with respect
to the Class Action during the Covenant Period:

    (i) Observation Rights. Buyer and Buyer's counsel may:
        (A) Attend all hearings, depositions, settlement conferences, and status conferences
            in the Class Action, whether in person or remotely;
        (B) Review all pleadings, motions, discovery, expert reports, and correspondence related
            to the Class Action;
        (C) Participate in strategy discussions with Seller and defense counsel (Buyer's
            participation is advisory; Seller retains control of litigation strategy subject
            to Buyer's consent rights in this Article 6.11).

    (ii) Expert Engagement. Buyer may, at Buyer's expense, retain its own litigation
         consultant, expert, or advisory counsel to:
        (A) Review the Class Action and provide Buyer with independent assessment of settlement
            risk, arbitration probability, and class certification likelihood;
        (B) Advise Buyer regarding whether to consent to proposed settlements or material
            litigation decisions;
        (C) Buyer's experts may not communicate directly with the court, plaintiffs, or
            plaintiffs' counsel without Seller's prior consent, and must maintain
            confidentiality of all attorney-client privileged and work product materials shared
            by Seller or defense counsel.

    (iii) Material Development Notification. Seller shall notify Buyer in writing within 2
          Business Days (or immediately if time-sensitive) of any material development in the
          Class Action, including but not limited to:
        (A) Court ruling on motion to compel arbitration (favorable or unfavorable);
        (B) Court ruling on motion to dismiss (granted in whole or part, denied, or mixed);
        (C) Plaintiffs filing motion for class certification;
        (D) Settlement offer or demand exceeding $10 million;
        (E) Discovery of new facts or evidence that materially increase or decrease settlement
            risk;
        (F) Defense counsel's recommendation to settle or change litigation strategy;
        (G) Third-party subpoena from regulators or law enforcement related to the Class Action;
        (H) Amendment to complaint adding claims, parties, or increasing damages sought;
        (I) Indication from court (oral or written) regarding its views on arbitration, class
            certification, or merits;
        (J) Potential D&O insurance coverage dispute or reservation of rights by carrier;
        (K) Disqualification motion or sanctions motion filed by plaintiffs;
        (L) Any development that could reasonably be expected to increase settlement value by
            more than $5 million or decrease settlement value by more than $5 million compared
            to the ranges in Article 3.23(d).

(d) Post-Closing Cooperation (Survives Closing). After the Closing Date, Seller shall
reasonably cooperate with Buyer and the Company in the ongoing defense and resolution of the
Class Action, including:

    (i) Witness Availability. Making former employees, officers, and directors of the Company
        (who were employed/serving during the period relevant to the Class Action, January 1,
        2019 through Closing Date) reasonably available for:
        (A) Depositions in the Class Action (Buyer shall provide at least 15 days' advance
            notice and coordinate scheduling to minimize disruption to witnesses' post-Closing
            employment or activities);
        (B) Trial testimony if the Class Action proceeds to trial (Buyer shall provide at least
            30 days' advance notice);
        (C) Interviews with defense counsel or Buyer's experts to prepare for depositions or
            trial;
        (D) Witness preparation sessions;
        (E) Seller shall reimburse witnesses for reasonable travel expenses (airfare, hotel,
            meals) incurred in connection with their cooperation, and shall compensate former
            employees for time spent at their current hourly rate (or $200/hour if unemployed
            or retired) for time exceeding 4 hours in any calendar month.

    (ii) Document and Information Access. Providing Buyer with reasonable access to:
        (A) Seller's business records, documents, and files related to the Company's operations,
            security practices, employee training, and incident response during the period
            January 1, 2019 through Closing Date;
        (B) Seller's personnel who have knowledge of the Company's pre-Closing operations
            (excluding attorney-client privileged communications or work product unless Seller
            voluntarily waives privilege);
        (C) Seller's IT systems and electronic records related to the Company (e.g., emails,
            Slack messages, documents stored on Seller's servers) to the extent relevant to
            the Class Action and not otherwise available to Buyer;
        (D) Access shall be provided within 10 Business Days of Buyer's written request
            (specifying the documents or information sought and relevance to Class Action), at
            Seller's offices during normal business hours, with Seller's counsel present if
            Seller desires;
        (E) Buyer shall reimburse Seller for reasonable out-of-pocket costs of providing access
            (e.g., document retrieval, copying, IT support), but not Seller's internal personnel
            time or counsel fees.

    (iii) Litigation Strategy Coordination. Consulting with Buyer and Buyer's counsel regarding
          litigation strategy, settlement negotiations, and material decisions, provided that:
        (A) After Closing, Buyer has full control of the Class Action defense and settlement,
            subject to Seller's indemnification obligations under Article 8.2(a)(xiii);
        (B) Seller's consent is required for settlements that would trigger Seller's
            indemnification obligations (per Article 8.2(a)(xiii)(H)(iii));
        (C) Seller shall not unreasonably withhold consent to settlement recommendations from
            defense counsel;
        (D) Seller's post-Closing cooperation obligations under this subsection (d) shall
            terminate upon the earlier of: (1) final resolution of the Class Action (including
            all appeals); or (2) December 31, 2029 (five years post-Closing).

(e) Remedies for Breach of Covenant. If Seller breaches any material obligation under this
Article 6.11:

    (i) Buyer may seek specific performance to compel Seller to perform its obligations,
        including injunctive relief to prevent Seller from taking prohibited actions (subsection
        (b)) or to require Seller to take required actions (subsection (a));

    (ii) If Seller's breach results in increased settlement cost or litigation expenses
         (compared to what would have occurred absent the breach), Seller's indemnification
         obligations under Article 8.2(a)(xiii) shall be increased by such incremental amounts,
         notwithstanding any caps or limitations in that Section;

    (iii) If Seller's breach is material and willful (not a good-faith dispute about
          interpretation), Buyer may terminate this Agreement prior to Closing pursuant to
          Article 10.1(e)(ii) (Material Breach), and Seller shall forfeit the Deposit to Buyer
          as liquidated damages;

    (iv) If Seller's breach occurs after Closing, Buyer's exclusive remedy is indemnification
         under subsection (e)(ii) (increased settlement cost) and/or litigation to compel
         performance under subsection (e)(i) (specific performance).
```

## IV.J. IRS BROKER REPORTING — FORM 1099-DA DIGITAL ASSET TRANSACTION REPORTING OBLIGATIONS

**Assumption Validation Status:**
- Assumptions affecting this section: 3
- Validated: 3 | Invalidated: 0 | Unvalidated: 0
- Analysis uses validated assumptions: (1) CTE collects customer TINs, (2) Form 1099-DA effective date January 1, 2026, (3) IRS transitional relief applies for 2025 transactions

---

### A. Legal Framework

The Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act ("IIJA"), enacted November 15, 2021, fundamentally amended the federal tax reporting regime for cryptocurrency exchanges by expanding the definition of "broker" under IRC § 6045 to include digital asset service providers.¹ This legislative change subjects cryptocurrency platforms to information reporting requirements comparable to those long imposed on traditional securities brokers, with first reporting obligations arising in calendar year 2026 for transactions occurring on or after January 1, 2025.² The amendments represent Congress's most significant intervention in cryptocurrency tax enforcement since the IRS first classified virtual currency as property in Notice 2014-21.³

#### 1. IRC § 6045 — Broker Reporting Requirements (As Amended by IIJA § 80603)

IRC § 6045(c)(1)(D) now defines "broker" to include "any person who (for consideration) is responsible for regularly providing any service effectuating transfers of digital assets on behalf of another person."⁴ This statutory language is intentionally capacious, capturing centralized exchanges, hosted wallet providers, payment processors, and cryptocurrency kiosks that take custody of customer assets.⁵

The Treasury Department issued final regulations on July 9, 2024, clarifying that the broker definition applies only to custodial service providers that "take possession" of digital assets during transactions.⁶ Non-custodial decentralized exchange ("DEX") protocols are expressly excluded from broker status because they facilitate peer-to-peer transactions without taking custody.⁷ Additionally, Congress exercised authority under the Congressional Review Act in January 2025 to nullify proposed regulations that would have extended broker reporting to certain DeFi protocol participants, further limiting the statute's reach.⁸

**Reporting Obligations Under IRC § 6045(a):**

For each customer engaging in digital asset sales or exchanges, brokers must file Form 1099-DA ("Digital Asset Proceeds From Broker Transactions") reporting:⁹
- **Gross proceeds** from each sale or exchange
- Customer name, address, and Taxpayer Identification Number ("TIN")
- Date of transaction
- Type and amount of digital asset sold
- **Cost basis** (for transactions on or after January 1, 2026, for "covered securities")
- Holding period (short-term vs. long-term capital gain treatment)

**Critical Effective Date Bifurcation:**

- **2025 Transactions (reported in 2026):** Gross proceeds reporting ONLY; cost basis reporting is voluntary¹⁰
- **2026+ Transactions (reported in 2027+):** Gross proceeds PLUS mandatory cost basis reporting for "covered securities" (digital assets acquired from the same broker on or after January 1, 2026)¹¹

This phased implementation reflects Treasury's recognition of operational challenges in retroactive cost basis reconstruction, though it provides only a one-year grace period for platforms lacking tracking infrastructure.¹²

#### 2. IRC § 3406 — Backup Withholding Requirements

IRC § 3406 imposes a 24% withholding obligation on gross proceeds (not net gains) from reportable transactions when the payee fails to furnish a valid TIN, receives IRS notification of an incorrect TIN, or is subject to backup withholding due to past underreporting.¹³ This statutory mandate applies to **gross proceeds** without regard to the customer's actual capital gain or loss, creating potentially severe cash-flow consequences for customers lacking TIN information.¹⁴

**IRS Transitional Relief (Extended):**

Recognizing industry implementation challenges, the IRS has provided phased relief from backup withholding obligations:¹⁵

- **2025 Transactions:** No backup withholding required
- **2026 Transactions:** No backup withholding required (extended relief per Notice 2025-33)
- **2027+ Transactions:** Backup withholding required UNLESS broker validates customer TINs through IRS TIN Matching Program

This transitional relief provides brokers with a two-year runway to undertake comprehensive TIN collection campaigns, though failure to validate TINs by December 31, 2026, will trigger automatic withholding obligations affecting customer liquidity and platform competitiveness.¹⁶

#### 3. Cost Basis Tracking Methodologies (Treas. Reg. § 1.1012-1)

The IRS final regulations permit only two cost basis determination methods for digital assets, eliminating the "universal wallet" aggregation method previously used by some taxpayers:¹⁷

**First-In, First-Out ("FIFO"):** The default method if the customer does not identify specific units before disposition. The first digital asset units acquired are deemed to be the first units sold.¹⁸

**Specific Identification:** The customer may designate specific units (lots) to be sold, provided the identification is made BEFORE the disposition and is documented in the customer's records or the broker's records.¹⁹ IRS Notice 2025-7 (issued January 17, 2025) clarifies that adequate identification may be made by reference to any identifier sufficient to establish basis and holding period, or by recording a standing order for lot selection methodology.²⁰

**Wallet-By-Wallet Accounting Mandate:**

Effective January 1, 2025, taxpayers and brokers must track cost basis separately for each wallet or account, eliminating cross-wallet aggregation.²¹ This regulatory mandate substantially increases complexity for customers maintaining multiple wallets across different platforms, as each wallet must maintain independent lot tracking and FIFO ordering.²²

#### 4. Penalty Provisions — IRC §§ 6721, 6722, and 6724

IRC § 6721 imposes tiered penalties for failure to file correct information returns with the IRS:²³

| Correction Timeframe | Penalty Per Return | Annual Maximum |
|---------------------|-------------------|----------------|
| Corrected within 30 days of due date | $60 | $630,000 |
| Corrected after 30 days but by August 1 | $120 | $1,260,000 |
| Corrected after August 1 or not corrected | $310 | $3,783,000 |

IRC § 6722 imposes parallel penalties for failure to furnish correct payee statements to customers, with identical penalty amounts and an additional annual maximum of $3,783,000.²⁴ Combined maximum exposure for non-intentional failures totals **$7,566,000** annually.²⁵

**Intentional Disregard Exception:**

If the IRS determines that failures to file or furnish correct forms were due to "intentional disregard" of filing requirements, penalties increase to $630 per return with NO annual cap, potentially resulting in multi-billion-dollar exposure for platforms with millions of customers.²⁶ Intentional disregard is established where the broker has knowledge of reporting requirements but consciously chooses not to comply.²⁷

**Reasonable Cause Defense (IRC § 6724):**

IRC § 6724 provides an exception to penalties under §§ 6721 and 6722 if the broker demonstrates that failure was due to "reasonable cause" and not "willful neglect."²⁸ The reasonable cause defense requires showing: (1) significant mitigating factors OR events beyond the broker's control, AND (2) the broker acted in a responsible manner both before and after the failure.²⁹ Documentary evidence of good-faith compliance efforts, vendor engagement, and prompt corrective action supports reasonable cause assertion.³⁰

**IRS Transitional Penalty Relief (Notice 2024-56):**

Brokers filing Forms 1099-DA for 2025 transactions will NOT be subject to penalties under IRC §§ 6721 or 6722 if the broker: (1) made a good-faith effort to file accurate and timely forms, AND (2) files returns within a reasonable period after the original due date.³¹ This relief explicitly does NOT extend to 2026 transactions, meaning full penalties apply beginning with Forms 1099-DA due in 2027.³²

#### 5. Precedential Guidance — IRS Notice 2014-21 and Notice 2024-56

IRS Notice 2014-21 established foundational tax treatment of virtual currency as "property" rather than currency, subjecting cryptocurrency transactions to capital gains taxation.³³ This classification creates information reporting obligations for platforms facilitating dispositions, as each sale constitutes a taxable event requiring Form 1099 reporting comparable to securities broker obligations.³⁴

IRS Notice 2024-56 (issued June 21, 2024) provides critical transitional relief, acknowledging that "brokers may need additional time to implement systems necessary to comply with the new reporting requirements."³⁵ The Notice grants penalty relief for 2025 transaction reporting, contingent on good-faith efforts and timely filing, but explicitly states that "this relief does not extend to returns required to be filed for calendar years after 2025."³⁶
